data.Context: Pain began with exertion while chasing his dog; persisted for 3 hours; prompted by wife's concern to seek medical care
data.Reason for Coming In: Central, squeezing chest pain radiating to shoulders; persistent despite rest; concern for cardiac cause
data.Onset: Mild intermittent discomfort yesterday; became severe 3 hours ago during exertion (chasing dog)
data.Evolution: Gradual increase in intensity; persistent since onset today; not relieved by rest or position change
data.Current State: Central chest pressure-like pain radiating to shoulders; 7/10 intensity; ongoing at presentation
data.Aggravating Factors: Physical exertion (chasing dog), possibly deep inspiration
data.Cardiovascular (+): Exertional onset, pressure quality, radiation to shoulders, persistent pain, hypertension
data.Cardiovascular (–): No diaphoresis, no syncope, no palpitations, no prior MI
data.Respiratory (–): No cough, no hemoptysis, no pleuritic pain, no fever, no orthopnea
data.GI (–): No nausea, vomiting, or epigastric burning
data.MSK (–): No pain on palpation or movement
data.Neuro (–): No lightheadedness, focal weakness, or presyncope
data.Constitutional (–): No fever, chills, or weight loss
data.PMHx: Hypertension, GERD, chronic constipation, cerumen impaction
data.Family History: Hypertension (father, uncle), thyroidectomy (mother), asthma and penicillin allergy (brother)
data.Social History: Smokes 1 pack/day × 20 years, considering quitting; no recent travel
data.Imaging Findings: ECG: Normal sinus rhythm, no ST-T abnormalities
data.Working Diagnosis: Acute Coronary Syndrome (Unstable Angina vs. NSTEMI)
data.Supporting Features: Exertional, pressure-like, radiating, persistent >20 min, unrelieved by rest, hypertensive, smoker, male age >60
data.Dangerous Differentials: STEMI, PE, Aortic Dissection, Pneumothorax, Pericarditis
data.Differential Summary: Most likely: ACS; Dangerous: STEMI/PE/Dissection; Non-critical: GERD/MSK/Anxiety
data.Symptomatic Relief: Nitroglycerin 0.4 mg SL (if SBP ≥100), ASA 325 mg chewed, O₂ if SpO₂ <94%, morphine 2 mg IV if persistent
data.Safety Cross-Checks: No allergies; monitor BP/headache after nitrates
data.Laboratory Tests: Troponin I/T, CBC, BMP, Lipid panel, HbA1c, Glucose
data.Interventions / Consults: Admit to telemetry, serial ECGs/troponins, cardiology consult
data.Contingency Plan: If pain worsens → cath lab; if dyspnea/desaturation → PE workup; if negative → GERD/MSK follow-up
data.Patient Education: Smoking cessation, medication adherence, low-sodium, heart-healthy diet
data.Red Flags / Follow-Up: Return if chest pain >15 min unrelieved by rest/nitroglycerin; dyspnea, fainting, sweating, palpitations; follow-up FP + cardiology 1 week

data.Context: 80-year-old male with several days of worsening diffuse abdominal pain, vomiting, constipation, and minimal gas passage. Prior abdominal surgeries and known aortic dilation. Stable vitals.
data.Reason for Coming In: Progressive abdominal pain, distension, and vomiting not relieved by home measures.
data.Onset: Began a few days ago, coinciding with granddaughter's birthday.
data.Evolution: Started as mild discomfort, gradually worsening with intermittent cramping and persistent distension.
data.Current State: Diffuse deep abdominal pain with nausea, vomiting, and minimal stool/gas passage. Unable to tolerate food or fluids.
data.Characteristics: Cramping, deep, colicky pain with waxing and waning severity.
data.Severity: Severe; 'never had it this bad before.'
data.Cardiovascular (–): No chest pain, palpitations, or syncope.
data.Respiratory (–): No dyspnea, cough, or pleuritic pain.
data.GI (+): Abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, constipation, distension, prior abdominal surgeries.
data.GI (–): No diarrhea, GI bleeding, or jaundice.
data.MSK (–): Chronic knee arthritis; no new joint or back pain.
data.Neuro (–): No dizziness, confusion, or focal deficits.
data.Constitutional (–): No fever, chills, or weight loss.
data.GU (–): Positive nocturia; no dysuria or hematuria.
data.PMHx: Hypertension, abdominal aortic dilation, osteoarthritis, chronic constipation.
data.Medications: Coversyl (perindopril) 8 mg daily; Lipitor (atorvastatin) 40 mg nightly.
data.Surgical History: Cholecystectomy (remote), ventral hernia repair (2014), wrist fixation (remote).
data.Social History: Never smoked, occasional alcohol, no drugs, lives in assisted living, low-fibre diet, mild activity.
data.Respiratory: Clear bilaterally, no increased work of breathing.
data.Abdomen: Distended with RUQ scar, hyperactive bowel sounds, diffuse tenderness, tympanitic, no guarding or rebound.
data.Peripheral Vascular: No edema or tenderness; pulses equal.
data.Working Diagnosis: Small Bowel Obstruction (SBO) likely secondary to postoperative adhesions.
data.Supporting Features: History of surgeries, vomiting, constipation, distension, hyperactive bowel sounds, stable vitals.
data.Alternatives: Large bowel obstruction, AAA, paralytic ileus, gallstone ileus, mesenteric ischemia, perforated viscus, diverticulitis, malignancy, fecal impaction.
data.Dangerous Differentials: Strangulated SBO, bowel ischemia, ruptured AAA, perforated viscus.
data.Differential Summary: Most likely SBO (adhesive); dangerous: strangulated SBO/ischemia/AAA/perforation; non-critical: constipation/ileus/diverticulitis.
data.Symptomatic Relief: NPO, IV fluids, NGT decompression, acetaminophen for pain, ondansetron for nausea.
data.Safety Cross-Checks: No allergies; monitor urine output and hydration.
data.Laboratory Tests: CBC, BMP, lactate, LFTs, amylase/lipase, coagulation profile, urinalysis.
data.Imaging: Abdominal X-ray, CT Abdomen/Pelvis with IV contrast, abdominal ultrasound.
data.Interventions / Consults: Admit to General Surgery; NGT, fluids, serial exams; surgical review if worsening.
data.Disposition: Admitted for conservative management with surgical monitoring.
data.Contingency Plan: Urgent CT and surgery if peritonitis or worsening; operate if unresolved after 72h.
data.Patient Education: Explain bowel blockage likely due to scar tissue; review management, red flags, hydration, fibre, adherence.
data.Red Flags / Follow-Up: Increasing pain, vomiting, fever, swelling, or lightheadedness; follow-up for AAA surveillance and surgical review.
